summary: Jim Garrison was the District Attorney of New Orleans who investigated the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The documents indicate that Garrison's investigation drew the attention of the CIA and FBI. MI-5 informed the FBI that the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation contacted Garrison to write an article about the Kennedy assassination. William Wayne Dalzell was of interest due to the Garrison investigation and had contact with the Addis Ababa station in 1956. The documents span from 1967 to 1976, showing a sustained interest in Garrison's activities related to the JFK assassination.
significance: Jim Garrison's significance lies in his role as a District Attorney who publicly challenged the official narrative of the JFK assassination and launched his own investigation, leading to scrutiny from intelligence agencies.
